entry.title: Re: Datasphere - SQL View - Set Business Name in SQL Select
entry.content:
I just tried this workaround:

1.- export the SQL view to CSN/JSON file (in Edit menu )

2.- upload the json file in a genAI chat and ask the following prompt:

" Can you update the attached CSN file and convert labels into Business names (Upper case lower case words without "_" )"

Gen AI will also ask to improve it like keeping upper cases for acronyms ..you can remove prefix or suffix..etc.. just be careful with json format double quotation marks if you copy/paste can replace that in notepad++ 

3.- import the CSN into the repository, wait the import is complete and redeploy your view.

Ref.-  Importing and Exporting Objects in CSN/JSON Files

example json code to be replaced/generated for that field

"VK_AUTOID": {
"@EndUserText.label": "AutoID",

entry.title: Re: Automated document submission to tax authorities from...
entry.content:
Hello @PChacon 

Thank you for your question.

The references below will provide some more details.

Schedule eDocument Jobs, Defining Interface Type for eDocument, External Documents

SAP Note 2134248 - Document Compliance Framework - Installation Overview

In summary, public cloud does not permit the direct background or event-based automation of eDocument submission from the eDocument Cockpit. However, you can achieve near-automation by combining scheduled background jobs and standard APIs/events provided within SAP DRC and BTP integration.

For now, I recommend using scheduled jobs to automate eDocument generation and validation, and if its critical to your business, I suggest you build a BTP iFlow or CAP service using SAP_COM_0527 to call the submit function automatically post-validation.

There might be the possibility for background submission of eDocuments through Event Handling Framework or Central DRC Service Orchestration in the 2602/2605 upcoming cloud releases. I suggest you keep an eye on the official roadmap.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: New Clean and Replace Feature for SAC End User File Upload
entry.content:
Why do we need a Clean and Replace Feature?

The end user centric file upload allows SAC users to simply upload (plan) data from a file. The new records uploaded from the file will either overwrite the existing records or will be added to them (controlled by a setting in the upload). But what about records that are already in the system and in the target scope of the file upload but have no corresponding entry in the upload file? Those records should either be kept or deleted from the system - depending on the setup of the planning process. So far there was no automatisms to purge the target data area.  Using a data action was difficult as the data action cannot know anything about the content of the file that will be uploaded.

So with QRC4.2025 we ship a new feature in the file upload that enables the system to purge the target data area before doing the upload. The logic applied is very similar to the logic used in the file import in the data acquisition framework.

It is possible to purge the entire target version of the file upload or the target scope can be determined from the content of the upload file. We will explain the feature in detail with a simple example.

How to use the Clean and Replace Feature

We assume we have a company planning the sales amount for some beverage products in various countries. The planning should be done by four different product groups: Juice, Water, Cola, and Ice Tea.

Let us assume there is already data in the system:

Now the end user wants to upload some new data. In the new plan that is captured in the file we only have data for two countries - Argentina and Brazil.

[Note: as in the current plan we do not care about product yet we will post the data to the product '#'.]

Let us configure a file upload for this file and model and add a starter to our story. As this is a well know functionality we do not describe in detail how to perform this task. You can find the details also in the following blog: 

New End User File Upload in SAP Analytics Cloud QRC3 2024 

Let us have a look at the result of the upload:

As we can see the data for Brazil has been overwritten whereas for Argentina we still see the two 'old' records (Cola and Ice Tea) that could not been overwritten by any records from the file.

Let us revert the data changes and go back to the modeling to use the new clean and replace feature. We change to the data management tab, find our file upload, and change the settings.

In the view of the upload details we open the settings screen.

Now we change the import settings to 'Clean and replace subset of data'.

If we do not select any dimension for scope, the system will delete all data in the target version of the upload. As this might be unexpected, the system shows the above information.

In our case we do NOT want to delete all data in the target version. There is data for other countries (like Canada or Mexico) that should not be clear as no data for these countries is uploaded. But we DO upload data for Argentina and Brazil and want to make sure that in the result we will only see the uploaded data for these two countries. Thus we choose 'Country' as a dimension for the replacement scope.

When we now run the upload the system will inspect the data contained in the file for the available values for the dimension country. As there are records for Argentina and Brazil, the system runs a delete action for all records with the countries Argentina and Brazil in the target version, and then loads the data from the file into the system. Data booked for other countries is not be affected.

Please keep in mind that you can choose multiple dimensions for the scope. In this case the system will collect the corresponding combinations and will clean the target area accordingly.

Please make sure to not just save the changed file upload job but move to the last screen of the setup and press 'Finish'.

Now we can open our story again and run the new file upload with the same file as above.

As we can see the two additional records for Argentina have been removed, the data for Brazil has been updated as before, and NO changes have been done to any data for Canada or other countries.

entry.title: Time Confirmation Unit Differences - Service and Asset Manager 2404
entry.content:
Hi,

Has anyone else run into issues with ssam recording time confirmation in minutes? (when entering 1 HR, it is recorded as 60 minutes).

In S4, we always recorded time with unit = Hours (to the nearest .5).  If we start recording time with ssam, some orders will have time in hours, some in minutes and others with both.  When using Display Confirmations, IW47, it reports back value and unit used during entry; this will be confusing and require some additional work to address multiple units when running ad hoc reports by order and/or employee.  I know IW37N will report back time in hours but then we lose visibility/breakdown by employee.

Any others run into this or have suggestions?

Bob

entry.title: Introducing the Next Era of ABAP Development
entry.content:
At SAP TechEd 2025, we announced four key innovations that redefine the ABAP Cloud development experience:

Key highlights:

  • ABAP is entering the era of Agentic AI
  • ABAP LLMs will be available on GenAI Hub
  • ABAP AI capabilities will be supported in earlier releases (SAP S/4HANA 2021 and later)
  • ABAP is embracing an open IDE strategy ‚Äî with Visual Studio Code (VS Code) for ABAP on the way

These innovations mark a major step forward in making ABAP development even more intelligent, flexible, and efficient.

Generative AI has already profoundly changed our world. The arrival of Agentic AI marks the beginning of a major technological transformation. We are entering a new era. For enterprise development, this means rethinking the very foundations of our programming models while upholding SAP‚Äôs core commitments to security, scalability, and reliability.

At SAP TechEd 2025, the spotlight is on how AI and Agentic capabilities are revolutionizing ABAP development. By embracing these advancements, developers can unlock intelligent automation, boost productivity, and build smarter, more resilient enterprise solutions.

 

A New Era for ABAP Development

ABAP is evolving alongside rapid advances in AI and development tooling. With these new innovations, we are extending the reach of ABAP AI, enabling agentic development, and delivering a modern, IDE-agnostic experience. 

 

ABAP - Now Powered by Agentic AI

Today, ABAP AI capabilities are available as individual Joule skills, offering valuable automation and insights to developers. To further enhance the development workflow and unlock new levels of productivity, we are introducing Agents for ABAP. All agents will be able to interact with one another through a new Agentic AI architecture in ABAP‚Äôs backbone technology components. With this innovation, ABAP coding agents will actively assist developers throughout the entire development process ‚Äî from code generation to refactoring and transformation ‚Äî enabling seamless end-to-end automation and agentic collaboration.

A new ABAP MCP server will expose ABAP development capabilities, both with and without embedded AI, to agents. Existing ABAP AI use cases will be refined and offered as tools or as dedicated ABAP agents via MCP.

Imagine an ABAP development experience where intelligent agents actively support you every step of the way‚Äîboosting productivity and accelerating development tasks through smart, agentic assistance.

General availability is planned for Q2, 2026. The initial scope focuses on VS Code for ABAP, with ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse to follow.

 

ABAP AI LLMs on GenAI Hub

To empower customers and partners to build custom, AI-driven developer productivity use cases, we will make our ABAP AI large language models (LLMs) available on the GenAI Hub.

Trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, these LLMs are purpose-built to explain and generate (ghost text) modern ABAP code.

Release is planned for Q4 2025, underscoring our commitment to openness and collaboration within the SAP ecosystem.

 

Availability of ABAP AI Capabilities in Lower Releases

(SAP S/4H2021, 2022, and 2023)

AI-driven development is transforming how organizations extend SAP S/4HANA. To make AI available more broadly, ABAP AI capabilities will soon be offered for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition.  From a technology perspective, we will follow a release independent approach by offering ABAP AI capabilities as an application that can be deployed side-by-side.

This allows ABAP developers in S/4HANA systems to increase productivity, accelerate custom code transformation, and continuously access the latest capabilities ‚Äî all while keeping their core system stable. The real strength of this new ABAP AI application is that it will be combined with the Agentic AI tooling described above.

General availability is planned for Q2 2026, marking a significant milestone in making AI innovation more accessible to every S/4HANA customer.

 

VS Code for ABAP is coming

To meet developers where they are, ABAP Cloud development is coming to Visual Studio Code ‚Äî one of the world‚Äôs most widely used IDEs.

 

The new ABAP Cloud Extension for VS Code delivers a streamlined, file-based development experience with built-in AI assistance. It is powered by an ABAP language server, initially supporting Fiori UI Service development and expanding to additional ABAP Cloud scenarios over time.
This move brings ABAP development into the same environment where developers already build with UI5 and CAP, enabling a unified, AI-enhanced experience across SAP technologies. Eclipse for ABAP will remain our flagship IDE for full-fledged ABAP development.

General availability is planned for Q2, 2026.

 

Join the Future of ABAP Development

These four innovations mark a major step toward a unified, intelligent, and modern ABAP development experience.

With Agentic AI, release-independent ABAP AI capabilities, and VS Code for ABAP, we‚Äôre redefining how developers create intelligent enterprise solutions with ABAP.

Learn more about the new developments in ABAP here.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4Hana public Cloud - APIs availability to progr...
entry.content:
Good day @SatyaPV 

Thank you for your question.

Here are references to guide you

Operations for the Bank Account Payment Diary Item API, Communication Scenarios, Create Bank Master Data for House Banks, Integration of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Source System with Central Finance

To summarise, in public cloud edition, it is not permitted to directly modify Bank Account Master Data through APIs. This is due to regulatory reasons and the approval workflow built into Bank Account Management. However, you have the possibility to read and have some controlled updates through standard released APIs and communication scenarios.

I recommended to:

  • Use API_BANK_ACCOUNT_SRV for data extraction and integration with partner apps.
  • For updates or creation, integrate through Fiori workflow or mass maintenance, not direct API calls.
  • For partner-specific metadata, use Custom Business Objects and Custom Communication Scenarios.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Who are you? Accountable or Responsible when standing for in the Fit-to-Standard process?
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve ever been in an SAP project, you‚Äôve probably heard someone saying:

 ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs plan and execute the Fit-to-Standard workshops!‚Äù

And then, a silence follows. Because ‚Äî let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî part of the room still wonders what exactly happens there.

So, let‚Äôs demystify it. üëá

Fit-to-Standard activities begin in the Prepare phase and continue through the Explore phase. However, what exactly should we do to improve and implement the SAP solution with as many functionalities as possible based on standard models?

The Fit-to-Standard process ensures that the customer's business processes align with SAP's standard processes, thereby optimizing the solution configuration to meet specific requirements. This process involves a series of workshops and tasks designed to capture all necessary configurations and integrations for a successful implementation, as illustrated in the picture below.

 Let¬¥s have a closer look at it:      

Here, in the Prepare phase, we will plan the fit-to-standard workshops (content, presenter, participants, time, location, etc.), test the relevant processes in the preconfigured system, define tools and templates, and provide solution training/self-enablement for workshop participants.

To complete the preparation, we will prepare the pre-configured system based on pre-delivered business processes or SAP Best Practices, adding additional samples of data and extending the system with selected customer-specific processes.

Now in the realize phase, we will execute the process review, system demo, and discussion of the delta requirements, if needed. Yes! If needed! If the standard functionalities and the configurations fit, we can proceed to step 7, as described later. However, if a delta process is required, we document it in detail and go to the design section.

 

Let‚Äôs talk about Design?

 

If we are here, it means that some standard functionalities and the configurations don‚Äôt fit. We are now entering a crucial stage where the project team focuses on defining and detailing the solution design based on the business requirements that have been identified.

We begin the design section by reviewing all backlog items (delta requirements) and verifying their completeness. We then double-check the backlog for missing delta requirements, prioritize them according to agreed-upon criteria (e.g., business value, criticality), and determine which requirements require discussion in a design workshop.

Now, in the design workshops/solution, we will document the business processes required for configuration and extensions, including master and transactional data. We will also create design documents and functional specifications to be written after the workshops.

Here, as mentioned before, we will finish the Fit-to-Standard process with or without a delta requirement. Very important: update the backlog with information from design workshops ‚Äì if any solution gaps are found. Review of functional design documents/specification. Acceptance procedure with customer sign-off!

But we still cannot answer our previous question:

To answer this question, we should know who the roles or personas are involved in the process described previously. Typically, as described in our SAP Activate framework, the roles involved in Fit-to-Standard are as follows.

We have these baseline roles that are crucial and very, very important to make the entire process happen and succeed. However, it is important to understand what they are responsible for.

To support you in answering that question, we have created a new accelerator RACI Matrix for Fit-to-Standard.

Basically, among the roles involved, we should define in each part of the process who is:

Easy? Not that much. In the example below, we present our view and perspective. As SAP Activate is a framework, by definition, a framework is a flexible, high-level structure with guidelines and principles, which means the RACI Matrix we are suggesting here can be adapted according to your project.

 This said, your RACI Matrix could look like this:

Important things to consider are:

  1. Assign only one person as (A)ccountable for each of the process steps.
  2. Formally validate the RACI with the stakeholders involved in the project.

Now, I ask you: Who are you in the Fit-to-Standard process? Let me know in your comments.

entry.title: SAP EWM Outbound Delivery Item Goods Recipient is empty in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear SAP,

can you please explain why the goods recipient in the EWM outbound delivery items is empty? 

  1. Open app "Warehouse monitor"
  2. Go to Outbound --> Documents --> Outbound Delivery Order and filter on outbound delivery
  3. You are able to see ship to party for this outbound delivery order.
  4. Now click on the button "OutbDelOrt Item" to display the outbound delivery items.

The goods recipient field is empty.

First question is: why is this even pulled from another table. Second question is why it is empty.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP EWM Outbound Delivery Item Goods Recipient is emp...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, the Goods Recipient field in the EWM Outbound Delivery Order (ODO) is not filled at item level by design. The system behavior differs from on-premise versions, as partner information is managed centrally at header level and not replicated down to each item.

Below are clarifications to your questions:

  1. Why it is pulled from another table:
    In the public cloud, the Goods Recipient information is stored at the delivery header level and transferred to EWM during delivery document creation through the standard integration layer. The data originates from the Ship-To Party (partner function WE) in the ERP delivery header, which is used by EWM for process execution. Since partner data is maintained separately from item data, EWM reads it from the partner table associated with the delivery header rather than directly from the item table.

  2. Why it is empty:
    The Goods Recipient field is intentionally not populated at item level, as EWM in the public cloud uses the Ship-To Party (WE) maintained in the delivery header for all outbound processing steps (including picking, staging, and goods issue).
    This is standard system behavior ‚Äî there is no separate Goods Recipient value stored at item level in the Outbound Delivery Order in S/4HANA Cloud.

If you need to use this information operationally (for example, in picking structure or RF transactions), you can refer to the Ship-To Party field instead, as it represents the same business entity for outbound processes.

entry.title: How to inactive unused Business Users?
entry.content:
Hello SAP,

Can I ask if there is a configuration in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System that it is possible to inactive user accounts that are unused for 45 days?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to inactive unused Business Users?
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

SAP has an application named "Schedule Locks for Unused Business Users" on which you can schedule a job to automatically lock business users who haven't logged on for a certain number of days. 

To get access to this app, you need SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR Business Role or SAP_CORE_BC_IAM_UM Business Catalog. 

 

Once you have access to the app, follow steps below:

  1. Open the Schedule Locks for Unused Business Users app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter a job name and click Step 2.
  4. Define the recurrence pattern of your job and click Step 3.
  5. Under Parameters, enter the required number of days since the last logon you want to use for the automatic lock. Please note that business users that were unlocked within the entered number of days range are not getting locked. This prevents manually unlocked business users from being locked by the job again.
  6. Add the business users you want to exclude.
    Carry out the following optional steps if required:

    1. Open the value help if you want to define further conditions.

      Go to the Define Conditions tab. Here you can define single users or whole user areas you want to exclude from the selection. You can enter multiple users at once by using copy and paste, for example to transfer users from lists.

      Please note that you can also restrict the list of users that should be processed by this job.

    2. Select Lock User w/o Role Assignment to also lock all business users that are not assigned to a business role.

    3. Select Skip User with Appl. Jobs to prevent the locking of business users with application jobs. By default, all business users with assigned application jobs are locked.

  7. Click Schedule.

 

For your reference, check SAP Help Portal | How to Lock Unused Business Users .

 

Kind regards.

entry.title: SAL: SAP 'Integrity Protection Format' secured with Distributed Ledger Technology on SAP BTP Kyma üöÄ
entry.content:
Did you know,

the S/4HANA SAP Audit Log (SAL) 

has a configuration, 

'Integrity Protection Format',

which enables (malicious) modifications to be detected:

2033317 - Integrity protection format for Security Audit Log - SAP for Me

2191612 - FAQ | Use of Security Audit Log as of NetWeaver 7.50 - SAP for Me

This integrity protection is an extremely important part of your holistic Security Posture.

As @kevinrichardson showed and stated in this excellent picture, 'You cannot solve today's challenges with yesterday's tools',

(Source: 002_rise_with_sap_kr.pdf)

In the ERP modernisation and transformation which is happening everywhere, there is not enough being done on Security Posture Modernisation, SAL: SAP 'Integrity Protection Format', is available now included in your License and enabled with a Profile Parameter, so why not to do it ?

The OSS Notes explain that, SAL: SAP 'Integrity Protection Format', works like this:

2033317 - Integrity protection format for Security Audit Log - SAP for Me

And that's all fine, but where does the, 'Distributed Ledger Technology on SAP BTP Kyma üöÄ' fit in to the equation, where's the relevance ?

Here's the answer, this Note 2191612 - FAQ | Use of Security Audit Log as of NetWeaver 7.50 - SAP for Me  has a pdf attached:  Explain SAL Integrity Format.pdf , and the pdf goes on to explain that,

'You should download the HMAC Ident as a backup, but you should save it on a secure place. The log files written with that can only be checked with that. It‚Äôs important to have this HMAC key data after a system copy or if the files should be evaluated in another system than the original. '

That's where the Blockchain / Distributed Ledger Technology running on the SAP BTP Kyma comes in,

store the HMAC Keys in the Distributed Ledger Technology running on the SAP BTP Kyma

This will ensure that nobody can tamper with the keys, and therefore nobody can tamper with the SAL Audit Logs and you have the least chance of losing the keys thanks to the built in characteristics of the Distributed Ledger Technology running on the SAP BTP Kyma, HA&DR out of the box, distributed, immutable, etc.

Source: BCP: Business Continuity Planning for SAP S/4HANA - made easy with Enterprise Blockchain üöÄ

Creating digital finger prints of data is going to come in to our Security Posture whether it's protecting integrity of AI LLMs or Document Grounding, Log Files, Backups and more:

SAP AI Security - How To: Tamperproof AI LLM's with SAP BTP Kyma and Enterprise Blockchain üöÄ 

Cyber Security Protection for S/4HANA Backups with Enterprise Blockchain and SAP BTP Kyma üöÄ

If you want to try it out there's a blog here, Running Your Own Blockchain on The SAP BTP Kyma Trial: A Hands On How To Guide üöÄ 

Have a think about, SAP Enterprise Architecture: Positioning Blockchain Database as an Enterprise Technology Standard üöÄ  and then you can SAP Enterprise Architecture: Let the Use Case find the BlockchainüöÄ  by following SAP Enterprise Architecture Principles and the Enterprise Architecture: Enterprise Blockchain Platform Business Capability Map üöÄ

And this is why, Why I love SAP and Blockchain Databases and why you should too üöÄ

If you learn one thing from this blog, it's that you can protect the integrity of your SAL Audit Logs with SAP 'Integrity Protection Format', and that is a cool feature.

Until next time,

Andy Silvey.

Independent SAP Technical Architect [you might also find my SAP S/4HANA RISE & BTP Toolbox interesting:  üß∞üë∑‚Äç The SAP S/4HANA RISE & SAP BTP - Toolbox üë∑‚Äçüß∞] and CEO of atkrypto (.) io

Author Bio:

Andy Silvey is a 26 years SAP Technology veteran [15 years SAP Basis and 11 years SAP Tech Arch including Tech, Integration, Security, Data from 3.1H to S/4HANA PCE on RISE and the BTP and everything in between, and former SCN Moderator and Mentor alumni].

Andy is also co-Founder of atkrypto inc, an startup whose ambition is to make Blockchain easy for Enterprise.

atkrypto (.) io's flagship product is the atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP,  and atkrypto (.) io is a SAP Partner Edge Open EcoSystem Partner. 

The atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has been designed by SAP Independent Experts for the needs of SAP Customers and to be deployed on the SAP BTP Kyma Runtime Service and leverage native integration to SAP Products.

atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has a number of unique qualities, including being the only Blockchain software in the world which has a DataCenter version and a light mobile version which can run on Edge/IoT/Mobile devices and enables data to be written to the Blockchain at the Edge where that same Blockchain is running on a Server in the DataCenter, protecting the integrity and originality of data from the Edge to Insights. Taking Blockchain to the Data at the Edge instead of taking the Data to the Blockchain.

entry.title: Re: Behind the Design: How We Transformed the ABAP Development Tools Architecture to Support More ID
entry.content:
Love that you shared this insight, super interesting.

I was actually hoping that you wouldn't go with the solution of headless eclipse for the LSP since that implies that we will essentially just get a wrapped Eclipse inside vscode. In other words, if there are things youre not happy with in Eclipse, you most likely wont be happy with them in VSC. And since Eclipse ADT is not open source, theres not much you can do to contribute to an improvement.

However I can absolutely see why this makes the most sense for you, keeping eclipse running as the primary IDE with maintainability in mind. Worth mentioning also that LSP generally doesnt specify any sort of standardization for remote repositories, so even with a LS implementation you will inevitably have to maintain some sort of client extension code to make the remote repository work in IDEs (that even natively support it to begin with).

I assume the remote nature of the codebase, and thus latency for backend requests, is the biggest challenge here? Otherwise the obvious solution would be to just make the ADT Service itself LSP compliant.

Sorry for my yapping here, I have been working on an abap language server for the past few months as a personal project and its been incredibly fun to get into all the technologies involved. So now that coincidentally things are also moving in the same direction directly at SAP, Im super curious to hear some thoughts on it.

Hello Tejas87

You should not use extension XSLX if it is not the real format.

ASC cannot be combine successfully with XSLX. It should be "BIN" if only the file is an XLSX.

Otherwise, using ASC format, the file should be in reality an CSV format.

If you really need to save in XLSX, you should think to use the ABAP2XLSX open source tool.

Or at least use function SAP_CONVERT_TO_XLS_FORMAT.

You can refer to demo program SAPRDEMO_TABLES_IN_EXCEL.

You can as well to look at that following blog where it has an ABAP program demo.

Download internal table data in XLSX from ABAP - SAP Community

Regards

entry.title: Re: Product Hierarchy Replication ECC - S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Good day @KatjaWa 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Product Hierarchy, Product Hierarchy Nodes, Integration

Products to Product Hierarchies Assignment - Read, Create

In public cloud, there is no standard pre-delivered replication flow such as an iFlow or predefined communication scenario to replicate product hierarchies directly from ECC or S4H private cloud. The reason for that is:

  • The product hierarchy model in public cloud is simplified and aligned with the clean core. It therefore restricts extensibility model.
  • Public cloud uses semantic hierarchies defined through Product Hierarchy Nodes and assignments, while ECC and Private Cloud rely on table-driven hierarchies.
  • The current standard integration flows cover material master, business partner, pricing, and classification data, but not product hierarchy replication from ECC to Public Cloud.

SAP provides two released OData V4 APIs for product Hierarchies in public cloud:

  • API_PRODUCT_HIERARCHY_NODE_SRV to read/create hierarchy nodes
  • API_PRODUCT_PRODUCTHIERARCHIYASSIGNMENT_SRV to read/create product-to-hierarchy assignments.

These APIs are currently the supported approach for integrations.

Below is step-by-step clean core compliant Product Hierarchy integration set up method.

Search for Maintain Communication Users app

Click New --> enter MDI_INBOUND --> set a strong password --> Save.

 

Step 2 is to create communication system. Open Communications Systems app

Click New --> System ID: MDI_SYSTEM --> Description: MDI System. Under Users for Inbound Communication, add MDI_INBOUND --> Save.

 

Step 3 is to create communication arrangement. Open Communication Arrangements app.

Click New --> Select Scenario: SAP_COM_009-Product Integration --> Create.

Choose MDI_SYSTEM as the Communication System. Verify inbound service URLs was generated automatically --> Save.

Step 4 is optional and it is to expose the hierarchy APIs. If it is not active, confirm your tenant exposes the following OData V4 APIs:

  • Product Hierarchy Nodes (API_PRODUCT_HIERARCHY_NOED_SRV)
  • Product Hierarchies Assignment (API_PRODUCT_PRODUCTHIERARCHYASSIGNMENT_SRV)

You can check them through Communication arrangements -->Inbound Services tab or you can also create a Custom Communication Scenario to add them.

 

Step 5 is to manage product Hierarchies in public cloud. Open Manage Product Hierarchies app.

Click Create to define a new Hierarchy Version.

Enter your chosen valid data --> Save.

Create Node and enter NodeID, and other details --> Save. Select a Node --> Assign Products --> Apply --> Save. Validate the structure. Open Assign Products to Product Hierarchy app to review the node-product mappings.

 

Step 6 is to confirm your Active Setup. Open Communication Arrangements again, search for SAP_COM_0009 √† ensure Status is active. Now your tenant is ready to receive product hierarchy data from MDI or ECC through APIs.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Landscape Strategy in the Era of Managed Cloud and AI
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs digital-first world, enterprises face intense pressure to operate faster, leaner, and smarter. Emerging technologies like cloud computing, AI, and next-generation ERP systems are transforming how businesses run. Amid this change, SAP landscape consolidation presents a complex challenge, requiring close alignment between business and IT. While it can simplify IT environments, reduce costs, and enable intelligent automation, many organizations struggle to find the right approach. This article aims to demystify the topic, offering executives a clear framework to evaluate options, make informed decisions, and maximize value through an effective instance strategy.

The Case for Landscape Consolidation

Historically, most organizations have accumulated fragmented SAP landscapes through mergers, acquisitions, and regional growth‚Äîeach business unit running its own version of ‚Äúthe truth.‚Äù These siloed environments inflate total cost of ownership, complicate reporting, and slow decision-making. Consolidation directly addresses this by unifying systems into a single, standardized architecture that delivers agility, transparency, and control. From the 1990s to the 2000s, technological limits‚Äîparticularly hardware capacity‚Äîonce made global system consolidation impractical. But today, with exponential advancements in computing power, cloud scalability, and tools like SAP‚Äôs Unicode-based Business Suite and Country Versions, technology is no longer the barrier. The question is no longer can we consolidate, but why haven‚Äôt we yet?

The financial argument is equally compelling. Organizations that have consolidated SAP landscapes typically achieve measurable cost reductions across key operational areas‚Äîaround 20% in IT operations, 15% in end-user services, 10% in application development, and 8% in maintenance and administration. These savings compound over time, freeing up capital for innovation and strategic growth. More importantly, a unified system landscape enhances global visibility, and accelerates decision-making at scale. For CIOs and CFOs alike, landscape consolidation is not merely an IT optimization‚Äîit‚Äôs a business transformation lever that drives sustainable efficiency, competitive advantage, and enterprise-wide value creation.

Beyond Systems: Why Process Harmonization Matters

System consolidation alone doesn‚Äôt guarantee efficiency. Without harmonized business processes, organizations often find that operational inconsistencies persist even after technical consolidation is achieved. In other words, system consolidation without process harmonization is suboptimal from a total cost of ownership (TCO) perspective.

According to SAP Value Group benchmarks, the typical cost distribution for enterprise systems is approximately 20% hardware, 20% software, 42% development, application support, help desk, and end-user training, 12% system and data management, and 8% other. The largest cost category ‚Äî development and support ‚Äî can only be reduced when process variants and customizations are minimized through harmonization and standardization. For this reason, almost all companies that embark on global implementation or consolidation programs also pursue global harmonization of their business processes.

However, while IT organizations often recognize the benefits of harmonization and may attempt to implement global templates ‚Äúbehind the scenes,‚Äù true process harmonization cannot be successfully driven by IT alone. It is not a one-time technical exercise, but a continuous business-led transformation that requires executive sponsorship, strong governance, and a clear change management strategy. The business must own and drive harmonization initiatives, defining clear objectives that align with organizational strategy. When processes are harmonized, they enable consistent data, standardized workflows, and measurable outcomes ‚Äî all of which are essential foundations for scaling intelligent automation and realizing the full efficiency potential of system consolidation.

Ultimately, while IT cost savings from ERP instance consolidation may reach 25%, the true value lies in achieving global visibility, standardized processes, and improved business coordination‚Äîbenefits attainable only when system consolidation is paired with process harmonization.

How Cloud & AI Have Evolved SAP Landscape Strategy

SAP has long been at the forefront of enterprise transformation. At the core of this evolution is a shift in how enterprises view their landscapes ‚Äî not just as technical environments but as strategic enablers. The pyramid structure in the diagram below highlights how harmonization and standardization at the strategic level (vision, strategy, and processes) are driving the reduction of system complexity at the operational level (infrastructure and projects). This reflects SAP‚Äôs broader goal: simplifying, standardizing, and automating across every layer of the enterprise stack.

The right side of the diagram captures how landscape simplification and consolidation have evolved in a cloud-first era. Hyperscalers have made on-premise (non-SAP managed) operations more flexible and efficient; however, the cost advantages of cloud operations are making regional or local systems increasingly attractive. At the same time, geopolitical disruptions and growing requirements for data localization are prompting enterprises to reconsider their global architectures. As business units evolve, organizations need modular IT landscapes that can adapt quickly to changing market dynamics. Finally, ongoing mergers and acquisitions are further challenging global IT solutions to remain agile and responsive.

While the drivers of change have evolved, the case for landscape consolidation remains strong ‚Äî especially when considering the transition to SAP S/4HANA as it presents a unique opportunity for enterprises to re-evaluate and modernize their environments. In the new cloud-first era, the key takeaway is that process harmonization alone is not sufficient. True transformation requires a commitment to standardizing on SAP best practices and processes. Only by combining harmonization with standardization can businesses fully realize the benefits of consolidation.

Landscape Options for SAP Process Harmonization

When consolidating SAP systems, organizations can choose among several landscape options that balance process harmonization with flexibility and deployment complexity. The Single Instance Strategy represents the highest degree of process harmonization, enforcing identical procedures and configurations globally within one system. The Virtual Single Instance Strategy, often called the full template approach, also targets global standardization but allows multiple production systems connected to a common template. This option achieves strong alignment across regions but requires significant upfront effort to harmonize processes and design a robust governance framework to maintain consistency.

In contrast, the Template + Multiple Development Systems Strategy (partial template) introduces a global development system for common configurations, while local development systems handle regional adaptations. This approach lowers harmonization effort but increases deployment and maintenance complexity, as changes must be coordinated and synchronized across environments. Finally, the Multiple Development Systems Strategy allows the greatest local flexibility but risks divergence without disciplined governance. Companies without adequate oversight often drift from standardized templates toward independent, inconsistent environments‚Äîundermining the benefits of consolidation.

Strong governance and well-defined change management are essential for success, regardless of the chosen model. SAP recommends establishing detailed governance and leveraging tools like SAP Solution Manager Cross-Landscape Distribution (XLD) to manage common configurations and automate object distribution.

Why Template Strategies are so Attractive

Template strategies are appealing because they balance the competing priorities of standardization and flexibility. While a fully harmonized, single global instance delivers high transparency, operational synergies, and seamless information sharing, it can also demand significant coordination and restrict local agility. Conversely, a highly decentralized landscape with multiple independent systems enables rapid local responses, minimizes coordination overhead, and preserves legacy practices‚Äîbut often sacrifices integration, efficiency, and visibility. In practice, the optimal point rarely lies at either extreme.

A well-governed global template represents the ‚Äúbest of both worlds.‚Äù It establishes common core processes and configurations across the enterprise, creating a unified baseline for reporting, governance, and automation, while still allowing local adaptations to meet regional or business-specific needs. This balance optimizes net benefits‚Äîachieving substantial harmonization without paralyzing flexibility. Organizations adopting this model can scale globally with consistency and efficiency, yet remain agile enough to evolve with market demands and regulatory changes.

Driving Alignment and Change Across the Enterprise

Consolidation initiatives only succeed when the business‚Äînot IT alone‚Äîowns the vision. CIOs and CFOs must jointly champion the strategy, aligning executive priorities and translating technical goals into tangible business outcomes. Indecision is worse than a decision; leaders must either commit fully to consolidation or abandon it. A half-hearted approach breeds confusion, wasted effort, and political resistance.

The business must first define why consolidation matters‚Äîwhether to streamline operations, reduce costs, or enable digital scalability‚Äîbefore any meaningful strategy discussions can occur. The opportunity cost of doing nothing far outweighs the risks of action. Inaction means missed chances for efficiency, growth, and long-term competitiveness. A strategic approach must therefore focus on optimizing performance through technology and process enhancements to achieve sustainable growth and market advantage.

Every consolidation journey ultimately aligns with one of three business scenarios. In the ‚ÄúWinner Takes It All‚Äù model, a larger entity absorbs a smaller one, prioritizing cost avoidance, risk reduction, and speed‚Äîoften driven by politics rather than process optimization. The ‚ÄúBest of Both Worlds‚Äù scenario emerges when merging entities are similar in size, each seeking to retain its systems and approaches, leading to cherry-picking, high complexity, and potential deadlock without decisive executive leadership. Lastly, the ‚ÄúCluster Selection‚Äù approach consolidates around relatively autonomous units, balancing flexibility and structure while reducing political tension. Each model carries trade-offs, but success in any of them depends on clear decision-making, consistent leadership, and an unwavering focus on the business rationale behind consolidation.

Decision-Making Framework: From Strategy to Execution

For complex organizations, making the right consolidation decisions can feel daunting. A structured, business-driven framework ensures that each decision is anchored in strategy, not convenience. Consolidation must begin with clarity on why a new landscape is required. The business must first define its objectives‚Äîwhether to improve visibility, reduce costs, or enable standardized global operations‚Äîand communicate the factors influencing consolidation to the IT organization. These include operational pain points, integration challenges, and the cultural readiness for adopting a global business model. Without this alignment and clear ownership, consolidation efforts risk becoming purely technical exercises detached from business value.

Once business intent is clear, IT and business leaders should collaboratively translate it into a practical landscape strategy and design. Together, they develop up to four viable landscape scenarios that reflect different balances of harmonization and flexibility. Each scenario is then assessed through an agreed-upon set of evaluation criteria‚Äîsuch as scalability, governance, deployment complexity, total cost of ownership, and change management impact‚Äîwith weighted importance assigned to both business and operational priorities. A structured decision process, often supported by workshops or governance boards, leads to a collective vote on the final landscape design and instance strategy. From there, a project roadmap can be established to guide execution. By following this disciplined approach, organizations ensure decisions are data-driven, collaborative, and sustainable‚Äîlaying the foundation for long-term enterprise value creation and true business-IT alignment.

Turning Consolidation into Competitive Advantage

The rise of SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Private and Public Editions), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and Business Data Cloud (BDC) has transformed how organizations approach landscape consolidation. These platforms provide the flexibility to run modern SAP systems across hybrid and multi-cloud environments, supported by AI-driven insights and automation.

SAP‚Äôs Business AI capabilities now automate repetitive tasks, predict trends, and enable intuitive, conversational interactions with business systems. By embedding intelligence directly into processes, organizations gain speed, accuracy, and foresight ‚Äî shifting their focus from data collection to decision-making.

SAP landscape consolidation is no longer a technical exercise ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic imperative for building an intelligent, agile enterprise. By harmonizing systems and processes, embracing cloud-native tools, and integrating AI, businesses position themselves for operational excellence and continuous innovation. In an era where speed and intelligence define market leaders, the organizations that master landscape consolidation today will define the intelligent enterprises of tomorrow.

Consider SAP Customer Advisory

If your organization is planning or evaluating an SAP instance strategy, our team at SAP Customer Advisory can help. We offer tailored guidance to align your architecture vision with business goals, accelerate transformation, and maximize value creation. Connect with me on LinkedIn to explore how we can shape your SAP strategy together.

entry.title: Mastering Financial Statement Design with Manage Global Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hi SAP Folks,

Back in 2012 I had published Financial Statement Analysis by using Report Paint... - SAP Community that revealed the excellent feature of financial statement generation by using report painter. Back then, there was no SAP S/4HANA and we were using SAP ECC, in SAP S/4HANA, SAP has released an app Named Manage Global Hierarchies App ID: F2918 to create/generate/maintain FSVs in various dynamic ways.

In this Blog post, I am going to share my experience on using this app to generate financial statement versions.

In one of my SAP implementations, I had a chance to use this wonderful FIORI Application to generate desired financial statement version for Balance Sheet (hereinafter referred to BS) and Profit and Loss (hereinafter referred to P&L). I have found it to be very useful tool to generate Financial Statement Versions (FSV) as compared to the traditional GUI based T code OB58. There is SAP note 3528582 - Two ways of maintaining FSVs for Fiori Applications - SAP for Me that beautifully describes difference between FSVs maintenance in SAP GUI Versus SAP FIORI.

All the FSVs that are created via SAP GUI are saved in T011 table while app FSVs which are generated by FIORI App are stored in HRRP (Hierarchy Runtime Representation Persistence) table.

OB58/FSE2 were used in SAP ECC and are still in use in SAP S/4HANA to generate FSVs. To promote FIORI, SAP introduced FIROI App. F2918 which provided more dynamic and flexible way to generate FSV. In the steps below, we will see how to do we generate FSV for Balance Sheet reporting.

I am using S/4HANA 2023, if you logon to FIORI then you can search for Manage Global Hierarchies App and depending on the authorization if you have, you see below FIORI tile. 

Manage Global Hierarchies

Standard Business Roles:

As per SAP help, following are the standard business roles that you may ask your authorization consultant to assign you to get the access of this app however there may be differences between the assigned authorization to select further hierarchy types like Financial Statement Version, Cost Centre Hierarchy, Profit Centre hierarchy etc. 

  • General Ledger Accountant (SAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT)
  • Overhead Cost Accountant (SAP_BR_OVERHEAD_ACCOUNTANT)
  • General Ledger Accountant - Intercompany (SAP_BR_RECON_ACCOUNTANT)
  • Group Accountant (SAP_BR_GRP_ACCOUNTANT)
  • Cash Management Specialist (SAP_BR_CASH_SPECIALIST)
  • Divisional Accountant (SAP_BR_DIVISION_ACCOUNTANT

Create Financial Statement Version:

We will now see how to create financial statement version using this app, once you enter inside the app, you will see below screen, you see here two main options, create and Import, we will explore both options one by one in detail.

  1. Create:

We will first explore the create option to create a sample FSV in FIORI bases financial statements. Once we click on create button, we must provide ID for FSV, name it needs, Chart of Accounts based on which its GL will be picked and Validity as shown below

FIORI FSV Creation

 

Click on Create, it might ask you to provide the transport request number to capture the changes depending on your client settings. Once transport has been provided, a new FSV Y002 will be created in draft status, you will now have to work on this FSV to create Hierarchy Nodes, assign GL Accounts etc. 

 

FSV In Draft Status

 

 

 

 

To exemplify mapping, we need to work on Assets for instances, we will choose Edit button from top right corner or simply can press Ctrl+E on keyboard to start editing process. 

I will select Asset Node as shown below and press on + button to add Sub-Nodes under it. I will add two Sub-Nodes under it and then assign GL to them.

Sub-Node Creation

 

+/- sign here implies that if it is selected that for the expenses GL which normally are shown with Positive sign, they will be presented in this FSV with - figure hence depending upon the selection of this +/- on a node , it will convert the underlying GL balances in that node from + to - or vice versa, it will not have any impact on the original GL balances in financial reports üôÇ

 

 We will now add few more sub-nodes under Current Assets and assign GLs.

 

GL Assignment

 Under cash & bank grouping, we usually have the requirement that if the balance of the these GLs are positive then it should appear under current assets however if it goes negative then it should automatically shift to another node under liability side let us assume Payable to Bank, this can be achieved easily by selecting on + for the Cash & Bank GL assignment and providing a contra node as shown below.

Contra Node Assignment

 

 Exporting to Excel and Working On it:

We can also export this FSV hierarchy to excel and work on the same FSV and then retrieve the mapping we did in excel back to this FSV version üôÇ. To me this is the most exciting part of this App.

Let us explore it,

Export FSV Y002 to Excel

 

 

Working with Excel

 

 

FSV Generated

 This is most stunning feature of creating FSVs using Manage Global Hierarchies App :).

Simulation:

We have now seen how to create FSV using Manage Global Hierarchy App, let us now simulate the FSV we have just created.

I have now turned on the simulate button and saved it, turning it on will allow me to use this FSV in the Balance Sheet/Income Statement Application in draft status.

Turn On Simulation

We have used above draft version of Y002 in Balance Sheet/Income Statement FIORI App as shown below and it is working fine.

Report

 Unassigned tab will show GL accounts which still are unassigned.

If you are okay with your mapping then you can activate the FSV and prepare to move this FSV to Production by transport .

Note: FSVs cannot be directly changes in production using Manage Global Hierarchy App, you must do the mapping in Golden client first, test them and then move to Production system.

Limitations:

The financial statement version Y002 which we have created using Manage Global Hierarchy App cannot be used in SAP GUI however FSVs which are created in GUI can be used in FIORI App for Financial statement, we can even import them in Manager Global Hierarchy app to redesign them :). There is one SAP Note that states the limitation 3064994 - Hierarchy IDs from "Manage Global Hierarchies" (F2918) are not saved into "Financial Statement Versions" table (T011) - SAP for Me

 

2. Import Hierarchy:

In your legacy system, you have created financial statement versions using OB58 , you might want to re-use them in FIORI Based Balance Sheet/Income Statement App by doing some changes to the GL mapping or node changes, to be able to do so, you can use this option to import existing FSVs. I had created one test template FSV 1300 in GUI OB58 T Code, i want to re-use this FSV in FIORI Manage Global Hierarchies-Financial Statement Versions, we will need to follow the steps shown below.

Import GUI FSVs to FIORI

 In above, we have selected Maintain Financial Statement Versions a Source and selected 1300 FSV ID to import in this app to do the changes. Once we click Ok, we must next provide the FSV name with which it will be used in FIORI as shown below.

FIORI FSV Generation

Once we clicked on create, FSV Y001 will be generated in Draft state, draft state allows you to make changes to FSV as many time as you want and you can simulate those changes as well. Alternatively you can use HRRP_REP T code to replicate FSVs from SAP GUI to FIORI platform. There is a wonderful SAP Note 3064950 - Financial Statement Version versus Hierarchy ID at Fiori reporting apps for Balance Sheet - SAP for Me  that explains this functionality.

I hope above knowledge article was useful to all the SAP geeks who are always looking forward to learn new things in SAP üôÇ. At then end , I would say Learn and Spread  the knowledge üôÇ.

entry.title: Re: Rollback scoping for Development Customizing Tenant
entry.content:
Hi Chin Yee,

Unfortunately, as I understand, it is not possible to remove an activated scope item.

Please see the support portal about SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition reprovisioning (link)

"Re-provisioning in the context of S/4HANA Public Cloud involves terminating the current system and delivering a new empty system for the customer to configure from scratch. It is used in special cases where there are no other options to undo unwanted changes, typically during the early stages of an implementation project. Re-provisioning is recommended when configurations in the Preset phase cannot be rolled back after activation or when a customer realizes incorrect configurations too late to make changes. To request re-provisioning, a support ticket should be created to component XX-S4C-OPR-SRV, stating the reasons for the request, which will then undergo internal approvals. Once approved, the existing system is terminated, and the customer is instructed to request a new system from SAP4Me."

Please reference the note: 3401017 - FAQs about S/4HANA Public Cloud System Reprovisioning

As I understand you will not receive the same URL.

If you are working with a CSM or assigned Solution Architect, please engage them as well. Otherwise, please engage your account team or implementation partner for guidance.

I hope this helps,

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: Re: Need to access Custom Business Object ODATA V2 API wi...
entry.content:
Hello @abinithim 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Creating Custom Business Objects, Mapping by Instance-GUID, Variant Tables Based on Alternative Data Storages.

To summarise, SAP_UUID is the mandatory technical key for all CBO ODatat operations. You cannot replace it with a custom business key like SalesOrderNumber for CRUD operations due to the systems clean-core approach and API governance. However, you can:

  • Query using your own field, then update through the UUID,
  • Implement a Custom Action to update records by your field, or
  • Use integration Suite to wrap this logic externally.

This ensures your setup remains compliant, upgrade-safe, and aligned with the extensibility standards in SAP.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Cost Center Upload - Error
entry.content:
Good day @EricAlo 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

CO - Cost center, Cost Center Hierarchy, Cost Center Group, Controlling Area.

In public cloud, when your cost center references a hierarchy node or controlling area that is not properly linked, the system triggers that Area 1 cannot be used here error. The reason is, in public cloud, the simulation validates format and mandatory fields only. The actual migration checks controlling area, company code, and hierarchy node consistency. The 10 cost centers that succeeded likely matched the valid controlling area while others did not.

To summarise, the error is caused by inconsistent controlling area or hierarchy node assignment. Ensure that:

  • The controlling area is correctly assigned to all relevant Company Codes
  • Make sure you use the Root Standard Hierarchy Node
  • All validity dates align across hierarchy, controlling area, and cost centers.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to synchronize a big table in a replication syste...
entry.content:
If you're using database level repdefs and subscriptions ("MSA", where there's one repdef and one subscription for the whole database),  you can use the Materializing Replicate Database from Primary Database Where User Activity Cannot be Stopped in MSA procedure

The advantage of doing it this way is, it uses a database dump to sync the primary with the replicate (while changes are happening to the primary).   This is way way faster than using BCP.

Ben

entry.title: Re: #COE#RFL01- How to neutralize free Payment
entry.content:
Please refer to the following Configuration Steps

Step 1: Payment Method Configuration per Country/Region
  1. Navigate to Set Up Payment Methods for Each Country/Region for Payment Transactions (SSCUI 101972) [1]
  2. Access your specific payment method configuration
  3. In the payment method settings, ensure the Payment Medium field is properly configured to restrict manual usage [1]
  4. Review the Classification settings to ensure proper payment method categorization
Step 2: Company Code Payment Method Settings
  1. Access Set Up Payment Methods per Company Code for Payment Transactions (SSCUI 101044) [2]
  2. For each payment method you want to restrict:
    • Configure Amount Limits to prevent manual usage below certain thresholds
    • Set appropriate Foreign Business Partner and Foreign Currency restrictions [2]
    • Review Required Master Data Specifications to ensure only properly configured vendors can use the method
Step 3: Bank Determination Configuration
  1. Navigate to Set Up Bank Determination for Payment Transactions (ID 101045) [2]
  2. Configure Ranking Order and Bank Accounts specifically for automatic payment processing
  3. Ensure bank account assignments are optimized for payment program usage only
Step 4: Authorization Controls
  1. Review user authorization objects for payment posting transactions
  2. Restrict access to free form payment applications for users who should only process automatic payments
  3. Configure role-based access to ensure payment methods are only available through the automatic payment program [3]


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better

Br.Bob

entry.title: Re: Multiple Questions Regarding SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Hi @byd, Maybe the below supplements that I got from the Japan LPM will also help.

  1. Yes, the remittance data output supports ISO20022 format, which is listed in Configuring Payment Medium Formats | SAP Help Portal  (JP_ZENGINKYO_I_XML).
  2. No Japan-specific solution. The Globalization team is planning to deliver a new app Manage Cost Statement Hierarchies in the coming release. The app is planned to be enabled for Taiwan first and might be enabled for other countries later. I will keep you updated if there are any progress.
  3. No JGAAP-specific reports but here are DRC reports for BS and PL for Japan corporate tax requirement:

    Balance Sheet / Profit and Loss Statement (Monthly)

    Balance Sheet / Profit and Loss Statement (Quarterly)

    Account Payable and Receivable books are available but not for JGAAP. For corporate tax requirement: 

    Corporate Tax Law Annex 21(4) and Annex 21(5) | SAP Help Portal

  4. SAP has many dates in best practices scenario. Customer can decide which date to be regarded as transaction date such as goods issue date or so. You can validate technical feasibility in output form customization and evaluate which date of S/4HANA best practice scenario reflects customer‚Äôs transaction date.

As for the PDF document storage, please refer to the note 3300746 - Japan Electronic Book Preservation Act and SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud public edition - SAP for Me.

entry.title: Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud test, demo, and development service
entry.content:
SAP Partners ‚Äî ready to explore the next evolution of SAP Business Data Cloud?

Join this exclusive session to learn about the new SAP Business Data Cloud Test, Demo, and Development Service, and how it fits into SAP‚Äôs product strategy built on applications, data, and AI.

We‚Äôll cover how partners can order the service through SAP for Me / SAP Store, understand capacity-based pricing, and explore tools to build, test, and commercialize data products and intelligent apps.

Plus, discover alternative test options, a 30-day free trial, and what‚Äôs coming in the 2026 roadmap.

ÊäÄÊúØÊû∂ÊûÑ‰∏éÂÆûÊñΩÁ≠ñÁï•
